description: From Middle English frossh, frosch, from Old English frosc, from Proto-Germanic *fruskaz (“frog”), from Proto-Indo-European *prew- (“to jump, hop”). Cognate with West Frisian froask (“frog”), Dutch vors (“frog”), German Frosch (“frog”), Norwegian frosk (“frog”), Icelandic froskur (“frog”). Doublet of frosk; more at frog.

examples: The mud hath in it certaine seed whereof greene froshes rise.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) A first-year student, at certain universities, and a first-or-second-year student at other universities.
examples: The frosh are really getting on my nerves!

verbs.description: frosh (third-person singular simple present froshes, present participle froshing, simple past and past participle froshed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To initiate academic freshmen, notably in a testing way.
examples: This campus does not tolerate froshing in any form.
Trying to open my car door with a coat hanger, I froshed the mechanism.
